Award.AwardTitle: The Role of Genetic Modifications, Age and Exercise on Cartilage Biomechanics using Genetically Engineered Mice

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cartilage is a thin tissue covering the ends of bones which provides a low-friction interface for the easy motion of articular joints such as the knee, shoulder, hip and others. The biomechanical properties and low friction of cartilage often make it possible for this thin tissue to carry high load with up to millions of cycles per year for a full lifetime. The genetic sources of cartilage properties are not well understood. This research will use novel technology to measure biomechanical properties of cartilage from mice that were genetically modified to determine what genes contribute to cartilage mechanical properties across the age of the animals. These assessments of cartilage function and aging will provide important basic understanding of how genes interact with activity and time to produce function. The results and new mechanical testing method will also have application to the detection of the early stages of arthritis. The application to arthritis could have a societal impact because it is a leading cause of disability for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. The biomechanical methods developed in this study will also work for measuring properties of other materials including artificial hydrogels and engineered tissues as well as natural animal tissues such as: tectorial membrane, ligament, meniscus and skin.

This multidisciplinary research program will enable for the first time a comprehensive and quantitative study of biological factors by measuring nano- scale solid-fluid interactions within murine cartilage tissue and key matrix molecules (i.e., aggrecan and collagen type II) over a frequency range pertinent to walking, running and impact-injury using atomic force microscopy. The knee joints from well-established mouse models will be provided from animals allowed normal ambulation and those exercised on running wheels, at three selected age groups. The research will determine the nanodynamic biomechanical measurements of cartilage tissue as well as of isolated aggrecan brush layers using an aggrecan decorated probe tip. These tissue and molecular assessments will be tested for their dependence on genetic, excercise and age factors to determine how the modified mice differ from normal.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report for the General Public
          This multidisciplinary research program focused on the role of genetic modifications, age and exercise on cartilage biomechanics, using genetically engineered mice. The research enabled a comprehensive and quantitative study of the cartilage of the knee and hip joints of mice. The rationale for using mouse models centers on the ability to studying genetic modifications and age ranges (including young, mature and aged animals) that can mimic specific aspects of the progression of osteoarthritis in humans during aging. The mechanical properties of cartilage were studied using loading rates pertinent to walking, running and impact-injury. Genetic modifications are only available in such mouse models; therefore, the unique methodologies developed for this study were capable of detecting cartilage changes that could cause disease relevant to the human condition. In addition, our theoretical and experimental methods have enabled quantitative studies of other mouse tissues including tendons, ligaments, skin and the gel-like tectorial membrane of the inner ear.
     The measurement methods that were developed for this program focused on the ability of cartilage and other connective to respond to dynamic or cyclic compression. Thus, a major emphasis has been the development of new technologies and instrumentation for such measurements, in particular the use of atomic force microscopy (AFM) for application of very small-scale compressive indentations. This technology is particularly relevant for the study of properties of small tissues from mice but, at the same time, directly relevant to the properties of the same tissues of humans. The instrumentation can also be used for other biomaterials that exhibit time dependent behavior including hydrogels and bio-engineered tissues and organoids. The methods can be further used to compare and test the effects of drugs for diseases such as osteoarthritis. 
     Our project may hopefully lead to understanding of the biomechanics and mechanobiology of cartilage degeneration and repair associated with osteoarthritis, one of the most prevalent conditions in human society today. We discovered that early degradative changes in cartilage tissue compromise the ability of this tissue to respond to higher rates of cyclic loading, particularly relevant to osteoarthritis as we age. Our recent studies of mouse tectorial membrane of the inner ear show that this tissue acts as a fluid filled gel over the ranges of hearing frequencies in humans, thereby contributing to the understanding of how we hear. And our studies of the mouse periodontal ligament under and around teeth are now contributing to the understanding of tooth movement, relevant to how and why braces in young children could be better used to achieve such tooth movement. Finally, our studies with mouse tendons have been focused mainly on the problem of rotator cuff tendon injuries of the shoulder, a debilitating disease in the human elderly population.
